Award.AwardTitle: Into Africa: The Initial Colonization of Africa by Early Cenozoic Anthropoids

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project investigates the evolutionary consequences of the initial colonization of Africa by early anthropoid primates (extinct relatives of monkeys, apes and humans). Working in Eocene strata exposed along the Dur At-Talah escarpment in southern Libya, an international team of scientists based at the Carnegie Museum of Natural History in Pittsburgh, the University of Poitiers in France, and Tripoli University in Libya will search for additional fossils and related forms of data bearing on the earliest known African anthropoids. The project will provide training opportunities for two postdoctoral researchers based at the Carnegie Museum as well as undergraduate and graduate students from the United States and Libya. Results will be disseminated through scholarly publications, popular media, museum exhibitions, and public lectures and seminars.

Understanding how the colonization of new landmasses by invading groups of organisms affects both the invaders themselves and the local biota they encounter is a widespread problem in organismal biology. Only recently has it become apparent that anthropoid primates experienced such a pivotal event during their evolution, when they colonized what was then the island continent of Africa from their ancestral homeland in Asia. This research project provides new data that will help constrain the nature and timing of this colonization event by focusing on fossil sites in southern Libya that have recently yielded the oldest known African anthropoids. By recovering additional fossils and other geological data from these sites, it will be possible to assess: (1) whether early African anthropoids are descendants of one (as opposed to multiple) ancestral Asian forms; (2) whether early African anthropoids experienced a dramatic evolutionary radiation after their successful colonization of that landmass, which may have been related to the evolution of modern anthropoid anatomical features; and (3) whether other Asian mammals may have colonized Africa at roughly the same time that anthropoids achieved their initial toehold there.

The project and its international components are receiving joint support within NSF from the Global Venture Fund of the Office of International Science and Engineering.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project has investigated the evolutionary implications of the colonization of Africa by early anthropoid primates (living and fossil monkeys, apes and humans). The earliest known African anthropoids date to the latter part of the Eocene epoch (~38 million years ago). Older and more primitive anthropoid fossils have been recovered in several Asian countries (most notably China, Thailand and Myanmar), indicating that anthropoids first evolved in Asia. When anthropoids first appear in the African fossil record, Africa was an island continent like Australia is today. Like Australia, Africa was characterized at that time by a highly endemic mammalian fauna that differed radically from the modern African biota. The earliest African anthropoids were thus
"invasive species" that must have impacted local African ecosystems. At the same time, the colonization of Africa undoubtedly had a significant impact on the subsequent evolution of anthropoids themselves, because an expansive evolutionary radiation of African anthropoids occurred almost immediately after the earliest anthropoids arrived there.

Our research has shown that the original colonization of Africa by anthropoids was phylogenetically complicated. More than one species of early Asian anthropoids seem to have colonized Africa at roughly the same time by crossing an ancient marine barrier known as Tethys that then separated Africa from Eurasia. Moreover, two different groups as Asian rodents (Hystricognathi and Anomaluroidea) appear to have colonized Africa at the same time anthropoids did so. We hypothesize that these small Asian rodents and primates were able to colonize Africa by rafting across Tethys on natural mats of vegetation that were discharged from the mouths of major Asian drainages during monsoonal flooding events that occurred frequently during the Middle Eocene Climatic Optimum. The fact that multiple groups of small Asian mammals were able to colonize Africa (some repeatedly) during a short interval of time shows that "sweepstakes dispersal" across marine barriers is not the completely random process that previous workers have suggested.

After anthropoids colonized Africa, they experienced a rapid and expansive evolutionary radiation there, which eventually culminated in the evolution of modern Old World monkeys, apes and humans. In contrast, Asian anthropoid primates went extinct soon after global climates became cooler and drier at the Eocene-Oligocene boundary. This important climatic event also impacted the evolution of African anthropoids by isolating populations of arboreal anthropoids in forest fragments that were previously connected. Rates of speciation and extinction of early African anthropoids were stimulated by the changing climatic conditions.

Broader impacts of this research have included training early career scientists (both postdoctoral scholars and graduate students), strengthening cultural and academic relationships among scientists from the USA and their colleagues in Libya and other countries, educational outreach to amateur groups, K-12 classes, and other interested public audiences, and the publication of popularly accessible accounts of the basic research in newspapers, websites, encyclopedias, and other media.
